Thomas Georg Karl Hirsch

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/5313832940724984
  • Última atualização do currículo em 01/09/2014

Thomas Karl Georg Hirsch finished his Doutorado in Mechanical Engineering at the University of Karlsruhe (Technical University) in Germany in 1983. Since 1984 to present he is Research Director at the Institute of Materials Science at the University of Bremen. 1998 he was inaugurated as a full academic lecturer at the University of Bremen. His activities are Mechanical Behavior of Materials, Behavior of Heat Treated and Coated Materials and Material Compounds, Improvement of materials for car and aircraft companies, Improvement of fatigue strength by surface treatments, Effects of residual stresses on the mechanical behavior of materials, In situ measurements of residual stresses, Failure analysis. 2007 he was inaugurated as Professor and Collaborator at the Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de desenvolvimento
2009 - 2011
Investigation and improvement of a manufacturing process chain from cold drawing processes to induction hardening.
Descrição: Manufacturing processes in general consist of materials solidification processes, metal forming processes and more than one straightening process, machining and heat treatment processes. Machining and final straightening is then necessary to guarantee the required shape and dimensions of machine parts. Few attempts are made to optimize products over more than one production step and difficulties arise from the fact that single production steps in a world market take place in different countries around the world. Cold forming processes are energy efficient and clean and are used in production processes with an increasing number. Cold forming on the other side significantly changes materials properties and cold formed automotive parts need a surface heat treatment or have to be through hardened completely to fulfill strength requirements. An improvement of properties during one production step consequently can result in problems in the next, one of the following or finally in the last manufacturing step. Components manufactured in this way show a broad band of distortions, which have to be removed by additional expensive machining operations. The transmission of distortion potentials from one manufacturing step to the other in a cold drawing process with additional induction hardening will be analyzed experimentally and partially modeled. A DoE-plan (design of experiments) of main affecting parameters will be used to identify effects and correlations. A reduction of one or more manufacturing operation as e.g. additional straightening and/or machining will be expected..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Desenvolvimento.

Integrantes: Thomas Georg Karl Hirsch - Integrante / A. da Silva Rocha - Coordenador.


Áreas de atuação
